Expectation1: Teaching children moral values and discipline
Situation1: The child is caught stealing snacks at a store, and the mother needs to handle the situation
Expectation2: Review and analyze case files thoroughly before hearings.
Situation2: A file for a straightforward procedural hearing scheduled in two weeks has just been delivered to your chambers for preliminary review.
Story:
I was still in my black robe when the call came from the store manager. My heart pounded as I listened—my son had been caught slipping a candy bar into his pocket. I rushed over, my mind racing with the weight of my two worlds. As a mother, I knew I had to teach him right from wrong, to show him that actions have consequences. I wanted to hold him, to comfort him, but I also needed to be firm, to discipline him so he would learn.

But as I sat with him in the car, my phone buzzed with a reminder: the new case file had arrived, and I was expected to review it thoroughly before the hearing. The court demanded my attention, my diligence, my impartiality. I felt the pressure mounting—my son’s tearful eyes beside me, the unopened file waiting on my desk. Both roles demanded my full presence, but I couldn’t give myself wholly to either. My heart ached as I wrestled with what to do next, torn between the expectations of justice and the needs of my child.
